Fig. 1 XRD patterns of various SiO2-Al2O3-supported metal catalysts after a reduction in an H2 flow. (The reduction temperature was 250 °C for Cu- and precious metals-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts, and that was 400 °C for Ni- and Co-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts.). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 NH3-TPD profiles of 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 (a), 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 (b), 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 (c), 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 (d), and SiO2-Al2O3 (e). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Pyridine-adsorbed IR spectra of SiO2-Al2O3 (a), 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 (b), 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 (c), 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 (d), and 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 (e). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TPR profiles of 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 (a), 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 (b), 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 (c), and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 (d). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Cu 2p XPS spectra (a) and Cu LM2 spectra (b) of the 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst after a reduction at 250 °C for 1 h. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM images and active component size distributions of 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 (a,b), 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 (c,d), 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 (e,f), and SiO2-Al2O3 (g). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 NH3-TPD profiles of 8Cu/H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different H3PO4 loadings. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Changes in the conversion of 1,2-PDO and the selectivity to propylene over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 with time on stream. (Reaction conditions: feed rate, 1.59 cm3 h−1; catalyst dosage, 2.0 g; reaction temperature, 280 °C; H2 flow rate, 60 cm3 min−1; concentration of 1,2-PDO in aqueous solution, 20 wt%.). Fig. 8 Scheme 1 Proposed reaction pathway in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propylene. Vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-propanediol to form propylene over Cu-loaded H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst Yue Li Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Huan Ren Methodology Formal analysis Daolai Sun Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology ⁎ Xinqiang Zhao Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, 300130, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Vapor-phase catalytic deoxydehydration of 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) to form propylene was performed over various metal-loaded catalysts in an H2 flow at an ambient pressure. Cu-based catalysts exhibited a relatively high activity for the formation of propylene, while other metal-based catalysts, such as Pt-, Ru-, Rh-, Ni-, and Co-loaded SiO2-Al2O3, primarily produced C-C bond cleavage products. Cu-loaded H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts showed the best catalytic performance, and the catalyst with a Cu and H3PO4 loading of 8 and 10 wt%, respectively, could provide a propylene selectivity of 95.0% with a complete conversion of 1,2-PDO at 280 °C. The Cu-loaded H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts primarily contained Lewis acid sites, and the Cu particles were well dispersed on the catalyst surface with an averaged particle size of 3.1 nm. It is proposed that the vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to propylene undergoes multi-step reactions with propanal and 1-propanol as the reaction intermediates. Graphical Abstract Keywords 1,2-Propanediol Deoxydehydration Propylene Vapor-phase reaction Biomass conversion Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is a key starting material in chemical industry, which is widely used in the production of propylene oxide [1], polypropylene [2], and a large variety of industrial products [3]. Currently, more than 100 million tons of propylene are consumed annually in the world [4]. The traditional propylene production routes are based on the use of fossil resources, such as the cracking of light oils [5,6] and the dehydrogenation of propane [7,8]. On the other hand, the catalytic conversion of renewable biomass-derived materials to produce valuable chemicals and fuels has attracted increasing attention in the past two decades [9,10]. Lignocellulosic biomass and bio-oils can be converted into a range of useful downstream products such as polyols [11,12], aldehydes [13], alkenes [14,15], and alkanes [16]. Propylene can be produced through some renewable chemical conversion processes, such as the sequential dehydration, dimerization and metathesis of bioethanol [3,17], as well as the sequential decarbonylation of biomass-derived furfural [18]. The conversion of ethanol to propylene can be catalyzed by various zeolites such as ZSM-5, whereas the yield of propylene does not exceed 30% [19]. The conversion of furfural to form propylene undergoes the decarbonylation of furfural to furan followed by the further decarbonylation of furan to propylene, which has a low atomic economy [18]. On the other hand, the deoxydehydration of 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) is also a potential route for the production of renewable propylene. 1,2-PDO is readily achieved through the hydrogenolysis of biomass-derived glycerol, and this process has been applied in industry scale [20–24]. In addition, compared with the routes with ethanol and furfural as the starting materials, the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propylene dose not release carbon and has a superiority in atom economy. Therefore, it is important and necessary to study the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to produce propylene. Deoxydehydration is an effective method for converting vicinal hydroxyl groups to form CC bond [25–27]. Re-based catalysts are the most commonly reported catalysts for deoxydehydration reactions, and in most cases, the reactions are performed in a liquid phase using homogeneous catalysts. Jefferson et al. studied the deoxydehydration of 1,2-tetradecanediol to 1-tetradecene over CH3ReO3, in which indoline was used as the reductant, and the yield of 1-tetradecene was 63% at 190 °C [28]. Scioli et al. reported the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to propylene, which was catalyzed by some Re-based catalysts, such as CH3ReO3, ReO3, Re2O7, and NH4ReO4 [4]. CH3ReO3 catalyst gave the highest propylene yield of 8% at 170 °C, while the main product was 2-ethyl-4-methyl-dioxolane with a yield of 41%. Gebbink et al. reported the deoxydehydration of 1,2-octanediol using CpttReO3 (Cptt=1,3-di-tert-butylcyclopentadienyl) as the catalyst [29]. The use of triphenylphosphine as the reducing agent gave a 1-octene yield of 93%. In contrast, the use of hydrogen as the reducing agent resulted in an over-reduction of 1-octene to form octane, and no 1-octene was produced. Although homogeneous Re catalysts are effective for the deoxydehydration of diols to produce alkenes, these processes generally suffer from several problems such as the high price of Re metal, the difficulty in product separation, and the catalyst recovery [30]. Palkovits et al. reported the liquid-phase heterogeneous deoxydehydration of 1,2-hexanediol to form 1-hexene over zeolite-supported Re catalysts [31]. The yield of 1-hexene was only 1.9% over NH4ReO4/H-ZSM-5 in the presence of 3-octanol, which was used as a reductant as well as a solvent. In this case, the acidic sites on zeolites promoted the undesirable dehydration of 3-octanol to octenes, which significantly disturbed the deoxydehydration of 1,2-hexanediol to form 1-hexene. In addition, the NH4ReO4/H-ZSM-5 catalysts showed a poor stability due to the leaching of Re species. Nakagawa et al. studied the deoxydehydration of 1,2-octanediol to form 1-octene over ReOx-Au/CeO2 catalyst with H2 as the reductant [32]. The selectivity to 1-octene was 76% at 140 °C and 8 MPa H2 pressure, and n-octane was produced as the main by-product with a selectivity of 8%. H2 is an inexpensive and environmentally friendly reductant, whereas H2 as a reactant promoted the further reduction of 1-octene to form n-octane in this case [32]. Nicholas et al. studied the heterogeneous deoxydehydration of 1,2-decanediol to produce 1-decene over MoOx-based catalysts, which provided 1-decene selectivities between 14% and 18% at 200 °C [33]. Tomishige et al. investigated the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over MoOx-Au/TiO2 catalyst in an H2 atmosphere, and a 1,2-PDO conversion of 45% with a propylene selectivity of 97% was obtained at 190 °C and 8 MPa H2 pressure [34]. Although a continuous process has many advantages in industrial production, the continuous deoxydehydration of diols to produce olefins is less reported. In this study, the vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to propylene was performed in a fixed-bed reactor over various metal-loaded acidic catalysts. The catalytic activities of the prepared catalysts were investigated at an ambient pressure, and H2 was used as the reductant. The optimum reaction conditions for producing propylene were studied, and the relationship between catalyst property and activity was also investigated. 2 Experiment 2.1 Samples 1,2-PDO, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, and Co(NO3)2·6H2O were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, China, and 1,2-PDO was used as the reactant without further purification. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was purchased from Shisaner Branch Plant, China. RhCl3·6H2O and RuCl3 were supplied by Bidepharm, China and Rhawn, China, respectively. H2PtCl6·6H2O was purchased from Shanghai Maclin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd, China. SiO2-Al2O3 (Si/Al ratio, 14.4; CAS number, 1335–30–4) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA. H3PO4 (85 wt% in H2O) and (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, China. NH4VO3 was purchased from Shanghai Maclin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd, China. An incipient wetness impregnation method was used for the preparation of the metal-loaded catalysts, and SiO2-Al2O3 was used as the support. The preparation process is elaborated by taking the preparation of 8 wt% Cu-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 as an example. Typically, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O of 1.342 g was accurately weighed and completely dissolved in 20 ml of distilled water. Then, a dozen drops of the solution was added to 4 g of SiO2-Al2O3, which was placed in an evaporating dish with the illumination of a 375 W tungsten lamp, and water was evaporated at ca. 70 °C at an ambient pressure. The operation was repeated until all of the Cu(NO3)2·3H2O aqueous solution was added to the support. After this process, the sample was dried in an air atmosphere overnight at 110 °C, and then calcined at 300 °C for 3 h. The prepared catalysts were kept in a dry environment for a future use. Hereafter, the prepared catalysts are denominated as xA/SiO2-Al2O3, where A indicates the species of the loaded metal; x represents the weight percentage of the loaded metal A. For example, 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 represents the SiO2-Al2O3-supported Cu catalyst with a Cu loading of 8 wt%. The bi-component loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared through a successive impregnation process using the same impregnation method as the preparation of the 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst. H3PO4, (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, and NH4VO3 were used as the precursor of the acidic components. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was used as the precursor of Cu metal. Taking the preparation of Cu- and H3PO4-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 as an example, H3PO4-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst was firstly prepared followed by a further impregnation of the Cu component. After each of the impregnation step, the as-prepared sample was dried in an air atmosphere overnight at 110 °C. The calcination temperature of the bi-component loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts was also 300 °C. Hereafter, the prepared catalysts are expressed as mCu/nY/SiO2-Al2O3, where “Y” represents the species of the acidic component, “m” and “n” represent the weight percentage of Cu and “Y”, respectively. For example, 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 represents the catalyst with a Cu and H3PO4 loading of 8 and 10 wt%, respectively. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The catalytic reaction was performed in a fixed-bed down-flow quartz tube reactor with an inner diameter of 15 mm at an ambient pressure of H2. Prior to the catalytic reaction, a catalyst of 0.5 g was placed into the reactor, and a 5 cm height quartz wool was filled above the catalyst bed. Before starting the reaction, the catalyst sample was reduced at a prescribed temperature in an H2 flow with a flow rate of 30 cm3 min−1 for 1 h. The reduction temperature was 250 °C for Cu- and precious metals-loaded catalysts, and that was 400 °C for Ni- and Co-loaded catalysts. After the reduction process, a 1,2-PDO aqueous solution with a concentration of 20 wt% was fed into the reactor with a feed rate of 1.59 cm3 h−1 together with an H2 flow of 30 cm3 min−1. The liquid products were collected in an ice-water trap at 0 °C every hour, and that were analyzed by an FID-GC (GC-2010, Shimadzu, Japan) with a 30 m capillary column of Wondacap WAX (Shimadzu, Japan). A GC-MS (GCMS-QP2010SE, Shimadzu, Japan) was used for the identification of the liquid products. The gaseous products were analyzed by an on-line FID-GC (GC-2014, Shimadzu) with a capillary column of PC-Al2O3/Na2SO4 (30 m, GL-Science). 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The specific surface area (SBET) of the catalysts was determined by N2 adsorption at −196 °C using a 3 H-2000PS2 (Beishide, China), and the SBET was calculated from the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms by Brunauer-Eemmet-Teller (BET) method. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded on a D8 Discover (Bruker, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation, and the analysis was performed under an air atmosphere. Before the XRD analysis, the catalyst samples were reduced in a tube furnace at a determined temperature in an H2 flow of 30 cm3 min−1 for 1 h. After the reduction process, the catalyst samples were stored in a nitrogen atmosphere. During the XRD analysis, the catalyst samples were exposed to the air without the protection of inert gas. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) analyses were conducted on an ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with Al Kα as the excitation source. Before the analysis, the catalyst sample, which was pre-reduced by H2 at 250 °C for 1 h, was stored in an N2 atmosphere, and the analysis was performed at a pressure lower than 10−5 Pa. The catalyst samples for other characterizations were not reduced before the analyses. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of the catalyst samples was performed using an Auto Chem Ⅱ 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) in order to evaluate the reduction behavior of the catalysts. The sample of ca. 0.10 g was pretreated in an Ar flow at 200 °C for 10 min. After the temperature was reduced to the room temperature, the Ar flow was replaced by an Ar/H2 mixed gas flow without the exposure of the sample to the air. The TPR analysis was conducted under the following conditions: flow rate of a mixed Ar/H2 (9/1) gas, 50 cm3 min−1; heating rate, 10 °C min−1; heating range, from 50 to 800 °C. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was measured using an Auto Chem Ⅱ 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) with a thermal conductivity detector. Before the adsorption of NH3, the sample of ca. 0.11 g was preheated in an He flow at 500 °C for 1 h. The adsorption of NH3 was performed at 100 °C for 30 min. The desorption of NH3 was performed from 100 to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in an He flow of 30 cm3 min−1. Pyridine-adsorption infrared Fourier-transform (Py-IR) spectra of the catalyst samples were recorded using a NEXUS-470 (Nicolet, USA) with a DTGS detector. Before the adsorption of pyridine, the sample was preheated at 200 °C for 1 h under a pressure lower than 10−3 Pa. The adsorption of pyridine was performed at the room temperature for 15 min followed by the desorption of pyridine at 200 °C for 1 h under a pressure lower than 10−3 Pa, and the spectra was recorded after the temperature was reduced to the room temperature. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the catalyst samples were observed on a Talos F200S (Thermal Fisher Scientific, USA). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over various metal-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts A series of SiO2-Al2O3-supported metal catalysts were prepared and tested in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO. The non-noble metals, such as Cu, Co, and Ni, as well as the noble metals, such as Pt, Rh, and Ru, were used as the metal components. TPR analysis was performed for evaluating the reduction behavior of the prepared catalysts. Fig. S1 shows the TPR profiles of the SiO2-Al2O3-supported metal catalysts. An obvious reduction peak at 224 °C was observed in the TPR profile of 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3. In contrast, 12Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 showed a broad peak centered at 336 °C, while 12Co/SiO2-Al2O3 showed two reduction peaks at 207 and 606 °C. In the case of the 1Ru/SiO2-Al2O3 sample, a small reduction peak was observed at 158 °C, which was attributed to the reduction of RuO2 to Ru metal [35]. No obvious reduction peak was observed in the TPR profiles of 1Pt/SiO2-Al2O3 and 1Rh/SiO2-Al2O3, which should be due to the small metal loading. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the metal-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts. The samples were reduced in an H2 flow for 1 h before the analysis. The reduction temperature for Cu- and noble metal-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 was 250 °C, and that for Co- and Ni-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 was 400 °C. The broad peak centered at 2θ = 23.2° in the diffraction patterns was attributed to SiO2-Al2O3. The diffraction peaks of Cu at 2θ= 43.4, 50.5 and 74.2° were observed in the diffraction pattern of 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, which were attributed to the (111), (200) and (220) face of Cu metal (JCPDF 04–0836), respectively. 12Co/SiO2-Al2O3 showed diffraction peaks at 36.6, 42.5 and 61.6°, which were attributed to CoO (JCPDF 74–2392). In the diffraction pattern of 12Ni/SiO2-Al2O3, the diffraction peaks at 44.6, 51.9 and 76.5° were attributed to Ni metal (JCPDF 04–0850), and the peaks at 37.1 and 62.9° were attributed to NiO (JCPDF 04–0835). The crystallite sizes of Cu, CoO, Ni, and NiO particles were calculated through Scheller's equation, that were 4.9, 5.2, 7.2, and 9.5 nm, respectively. The diffraction peak attributed to noble metals was not observed, which should be due to the small loading and the high dispersion of the noble metals. Table 1 shows the reaction results in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to propylene over various supported metal catalysts in an H2 flow at 250 °C. The catalyst dosage was 0.5 g, and a 1,2-PDO aqueous solution with a 1,2-PDO concentration of 20 wt% was used as the reactant. Propylene, propanal, 1-propanol, propane, acetone, acetol, and propionic acid (PA) were detected as the products. Some unidentified liquid products were also formed. The mass balance in the reactions, which involved all the detected products including the unidentified products, was at a range of 87–99%. 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 exhibited a relatively high activity for the formation of propylene. The conversion of 1,2-PDO and the selectivity to propylene were 99.8 and 11.3%, respectively. Meanwhile, propanal and 1-propanol were produced with a selectivity of 10.6 and 57.8%, respectively. 12Cu/H-USY, 12Cu/H-Mordenite, and 12Cu/H-ZSM-5 provided relatively high selectivities to propanal, that were 55.5, 47.7, and 21.2%, respectively, whereas propylene was less produced. On the other hand, 12Cu/γ-Al2O3 primarily produced acetol with a selectivity of 50%. Both Ni- and Co-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts provided a high 1,2-PDO conversion of 99.7%, whereas the C-C cleavage products, including methane, ethane, ethylene, acetaldehyde, and ethanol, were produced with a large amount. For example, 12Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst produced methane and ethane with a selectivity of 27.7 and 36.5%, respectively. In the case of 12Co/SiO2-Al2O3, ethanol was produced with a selectivity of 29.7%. Noble metal-loaded catalysts showed a high catalytic activity, and Pt-, Rh-, and Ru-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts provided almost a complete conversion of 1,2-PDO at 250 °C. However, the major product was ethane in the reactions catalyzed by noble metal catalysts. The selectivity to ethane was 57.5, 77.6, and 43.2% over 1Pt/SiO2-Al2O3, 1Rh/SiO2-Al2O3, and 1Ru/SiO2-Al2O3, respectively. The catalytic activity of 1Ru/SiO2-Al2O3 was also investigated at a relatively low temperature of 200 °C. The conversion of 1,2-PDO was decreased to 21.3%, while ethane was still produced with a relatively high selectivity of 18.4%. Because Ni-, Co-, and noble metals-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts exhibited a high activity for the cleavage of C-C bond, these catalysts were not suitable for the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to produce propylene. In contrast, 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 provided a relatively high selectivity to propylene, and the C-C bond cleavage of 1,2-PDO almost did not proceed. The deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cu loadings was investigated at 250 °C. As shown in Table 2, the conversion of 1,2-PDO was higher than 99% over the Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with a Cu loading of 2–12 wt%. When the loading of Cu increased from 12 to 16 wt%, the conversion of 1,2-PDO decreased from 99.7% to 95.2%. The selectivity to propanal was 44.3% at a Cu loading of 2 wt%, which gradually decreased with increasing the Cu loading. Since Cu metal is active for the hydrogenation of aldehydes [36,37], the decrement in the selectivity to propanal at high Cu loadings should be due to the promoted hydrogenation of propanal to form 1-propanol. On the other hand, the selectivity to propylene and 1-propanol showed a similar changing trend with increasing the loading of Cu. A moderate Cu loading of 4–8 wt% promoted the formation of both propylene and 1-propanol. 1-Propanol can be dehydrated to form propylene over acidic sites [38]. Therefore, 1-propanol was supposed as an intermediate in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propylene. According to the above reaction results, a reaction pathway in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to propylene over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts is proposed. As shown in Scheme 1, propanal was firstly produced through the dehydration of 1,2-PDO, which was further hydrogenated to produce 1-propanol, and propylene was finally produced through the dehydration of 1-propanol. Jefferson et al. have studied the reaction mechanism in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-diols over CH3ReO3, in which indoline was used as the reductant. Initially, Re7+ was reduced to Re5+ by indoline, and then the adjacent two OH groups in a 1,2-diol were attacked by CH3ReO2 2-, resulting in the formation of a rhenium diolate intermediate. Finally, an olefin was formed simultaneously with the formation of CH3ReO3 [28]. In contrast, the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO in the present study catalyzed by Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 proceeded through dehydration-hydrogenation-dehydration multi-step reactions. The acid sites on Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 should work for the dehydration processes including the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propanal and the dehydration of 1-propanol to form propylene, and the Cu metal should work for the hydrogenation process. 3.2 Deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over Cu catalysts supported by acidic component-modified SiO2-Al2O3 As shown in Scheme 1, the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to propanal and the dehydration of 1-propanol to propylene are two important steps in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propylene. Both of the two dehydration steps should be catalyzed by the acid sites on 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 [39–41]. On the other hand, as shown in Table 2, the catalytic ability of 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 was not insufficient to completely catalyze the dehydration of 1-propanol to form propylene. To improve the catalytic performance, before the loading of Cu, SiO2-Al2O3 was modified by some acidic components, such as H3PO4, MoO3, and V2O5, and the effect of introducing acidic components was investigated. The texture parameters of the acidic component-introduced catalysts are shown in Table S1. The SBET and the pore volume of the 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 sample were 383 m2 g−1 and 0.54 cm3 g−1, respectively. The addition of acidic components decreased both the SBET and the pore volume, and that of 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 were decreased to 296 m2 g−1 and 0.43 cm3 g−1, respectively. The averaged pore sizes of 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3, and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 were 5.8, 6.2, and 6.3 nm, respectively. Fig. S2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the acidic component-introduced catalysts, and all of the catalyst samples showed adsorption-desorption isotherms of Type Ⅳ, suggesting that the samples primarily contained mesopores. Fig. 2 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of the acidic component-introduced catalysts. The acid amount of the SiO2-Al2O3 support was 402 μmol g−1, and that of 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3, and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 was 394, 477, 470, and 414 μmol g−1, respectively. The addition of the acidic components increased the amount of acid sites, and 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 showed the largest acid amount. SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 showed a desorption peak at 193 and 207 °C, respectively. The addition of the acidic components affected the acid distribution, and all of the acidic component-introduced catalyst samples showed two or three desorption peaks. 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 showed two desorption peaks at 194 and 281 °C, and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 showed two desorption peaks at 198 and 304 °C. The desorption peaks of 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 were observed at 201, 291, and 330 °C. Fig. 3 shows the Py-IR spectra of the acidic component-introduced catalysts. The peaks centralized at 1543 and 1452 cm−1 could be observed in the Py-IR spectra of all the catalyst samples, which were corresponding to the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively [42,43]. This result indicates that all the catalyst samples contained both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, however, the ratio of Lewis/Brønsted acid sites (L/B) of the catalyst samples was much different. The L/B ratio of SiO2-Al2O3 was 1.4, and that of 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 was 12.5, indicating that the loading of Cu dramatically reduced the amount of Brønsted acid sites. The L/B ratio for 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3, and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 were 8.9, 7.5, and 3.4, respectively, indicating that all of the three catalysts primarily contained Lewis acid sites. Meanwhile, among the acidic component-introduced catalysts, 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 had the largest L/B ratio. Fig. S3 shows the XRD patterns of the acidic component-introduced catalysts. No diffraction peak attributed to Cu was observed in the XRD patterns of all of the samples, indicating the high dispersion of Cu particles on the catalyst surface. Fig. 4 shows the TPR profiles of the acidic component-introduced catalysts. 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 showed reduction peaks at 225 and 235 °C, respectively. In contrast, 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 showed reduction peaks at relatively high temperatures of 289 and 299 °C, respectively. The H2 consumption amounts were 1.31 and 1.21 mmol/gcat for 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, respectively, which were close to the theoretical CuO amount of 1.25 mmol/gcat, suggesting that H2 was consumed for the reduction of CuO to a metallic state. On the other hand, the H2 consumption amounts were 1.67 and 2.13 mmol/gcat for 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3, respectively, and the excessive H2 consumption was possibly due to the partial reduction of MoO3 and V2O5 [44]. The above analysis results indicate that the species of the additive acidic component affected the reduction behavior of Cu oxides. Compared with 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3, 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 was more easily to reduced and activated by H2. XPS analysis of the 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 sample, which was pre-reduced at 250 °C for 1 h, were performed. Fig. 5(a) displays the XPS spectra of Cu 2p. The peaks at the binding energy of 932.8 and 952.5 eV were attributed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2, respectively, and both of them could be deconvoluted into two peaks. The obvious peaks at 932.8 and 952.3 eV were attributed to Cu+ and/or Cu0, and the small peaks at 935.1 and 954.5 eV were attributed to Cu2+ [45]. AES analysis was further performed to identify Cu0 and Cu+ species on the catalyst surface. The Cu LM2 spectra of 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 is shown in Fig. 5(b). The peak at 568.2 eV was attributed to Cu0, and the small peak at 570.9 eV was attributed to Cu+ [46,47]. The XPS and AES analyses results indicate that the surface Cu species in the 250 °C-reduced 8Cu/10 H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 primarily existed as a form of Cu0 with a small amount of Cu+ and Cu2+. Fig. 6 displays the TEM images and the Cu particle size distributions of the acidic component-introduced catalysts. Cu particles were not observed in the TEM image of the SiO2-Al2O3 support (Fig. 6g), and that were clearly observed in the TEM image of the 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 sample (Fig. 6a). Cu particles were well dispersed on the surface of the 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 sample with an averaged particle size of 3.1 nm. By comparison, the averaged active component size of 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 was 6.3 and 5.2 nm, respectively. Generally, a small metal particle is more easily to be reduced. Therefore, 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 with a small particle size could be reduced at a relatively low temperature as shown in Fig. 6. Table 3 shows the reaction results in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over the acidic component-introduced catalysts. The amount of each acidic component in the corresponding catalyst was 10 wt%. The reactions were performed in an H2 flow at 250 °C with a catalyst dosage of 0.5 g. Compared with 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, the addition of H3PO4 significantly promoted the formation of propylene, and a propylene selectivity of 33.6% was obtained at a 1,2-PDO conversion of 99.8%. The reaction over 10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 without Cu loading was also performed, and propanal was primarily produced with a selectivity of 62.7%, indicating that Cu metal worked for the further hydrogenation of propanal to form 1-propanol. The selectivity to propylene was 14.2 and 5.4% over 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3, respectively. The selectivity to propanal was 7.5% over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, whereas that was 22.0 and 26.1% over 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3, respectively. The relatively high selectivities to propanal indicated that the MoO3- and V2O5-introduced catalysts were less effective for the hydrogenation of propanal. As shown in Fig. 6, compared with 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, the Cu particle sizes of 8Cu/10MoO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/10V2O5/SiO2-Al2O3 were larger. Generally, a metal catalyst with a small particle size is more active for a hydrogenation process. Therefore, the high activity of 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 for the hydrogenation of propanal should be due to the well dispersion of Cu particles. On the other hand, the introduction of H3PO4 promoted the dehydration of 1-propanol to form propylene, which was possibly due to the increment in the amount of acid sites (Fig. 2). As shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 showed the largest amount of acid sites with a high L/B ratio, suggesting that the abundant Lewis acid sites were beneficial for the efficient formation of propylene. In order to verify the reaction routes in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, some possible reaction intermediates, such as propanal, 1-propanol, acetone, and acetol, were selected as the starting materials. As shown in Table 4, in the reaction with propanal as the reactant, 1-propanol and propylene were primarily produced with a selectivity of 19.3% and 77.1%, respectively. In the reaction with 1-propanol as the reactant, a high propylene selectivity of 92.7% was obtained. The above reaction results demonstrated our proposed reaction routes, in which propanal and 1-propanol were the reaction intermediates. On the other hand, acetol and acetone also could be converted to form propylene, indicating the variety of the formation routes of propylene. However, because 10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 without Cu loading primarily produced propanal (Table 3), our proposed dehydration-hydrogenation-dehydration route should be the main formation route of propylene. 3.3 Deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over Cu/H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 with different H3PO4 loadings The effect of the loading of H3PO4 in Cu/H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts was studied. Table 5 summarizes the texture parameters of the 8Cu/H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different H3PO4 loadings. The SBET, pore volume, and averaged pore size of 8Cu/5H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 sample were 345 m2 g−1, 0.52 cm3 g−1, and 6.0 nm, respectively, and all of the three parameters gradually decreased with the increment in the H3PO4 loading at a range of 5–20 wt%. The decrement in SBET at a large H3PO4 loading must be due to the decrement in the content of the SiO2-Al2O3 support. On the other hand, the decrement in pore volume and averaged pore size at a large H3PO4 loading indicates that H3PO4 is loaded in the mesopores of the SiO2-Al2O3 support. Fig. 7 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of the 8Cu/H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different H3PO4 loadings. The acid amount of 8Cu/5H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, 8Cu/15H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, and 8Cu/20H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 were 415, 477, 350, and 250 μmol g−1, respectively. The acid amount increased with increasing the loading of H3PO4 up to 10 wt%. With the increment in H3PO4 loading from 10 to 20 wt%, the acid amount of the catalysts showed a decreasing trend, which should be due to the reduction of the SBET at a large H3PO4 loading. Table 6 shows the reaction results in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over the 8Cu/H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different H3PO4 loadings. The conversion of 1,2-PDO and the selectivity to propylene were 99.9 and 29.1% over 8Cu/5H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3, respectively. With the increment in H3PO4 loading from 5 to 20 wt%, the conversion of 1,2-PDO gradually decreased from 99.9% to 65.8%. Because the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to propanal, which is the first step reaction in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO, was catalyzed by acid sites, the low conversion at a high H3PO4 loading is possibly due to the small acid amount. In addition, when the loading of H3PO4 increased from 10 to 20 wt%, the selectivity to propanal increased from 7.5% to 28.6%, indicating that a large loading of H3PO4 reduced the catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of propanal. 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 provided the highest propylene selectivity of 33.6%, indicating that the suitable H3PO4 loading for producing propylene was ca. 10 wt%. 3.4 Deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 at different reaction conditions The influence of the H2 concentration was studied. Table 7 summarizes the reaction results in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 at different H2 flow rates. The conversion of 1,2-PDO gradually increased with increasing the H2 flow rate up to 60 cm3 min−1. A complete conversion of 1,2-PDO was achieved at an H2 flow rate of 60 cm3 min−1, and a higher H2 flow rate of 90 cm3 min−1 reduced the conversion of 1,2-PDO to 94.8%. The selectivity of propanal decreased with the increasing of the H2 flow rate, indicating that a high concentration of H2 could promote the hydrogenation of propanal. On the other hand, the selectivity to propane increased with increasing the H2 flow rate, indicating that a high H2 concentration also promoted the further hydrogenation of propylene to form propane. Table 8 summarizes the reaction results in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 at different reaction temperatures. The conversion of 1,2-PDO increased with increasing the reaction temperature, and a complete conversion of 1,2-PDO was achieved at a temperature higher than 280 °C. The reaction temperature significantly affected the selectivity to propylene. The selectivity to propylene was only 0.5% at 200 °C, which increased with increasing the temperature up to 300 °C. Acetol was primarily produced at a low temperature of 200 °C, which significantly decreased with increasing the temperature, and the selectivity to acetol was lower than 2.0% at a temperature higher than 250 °C. A high temperature promoted the formation of PA and acetone. The selectivity to 1-propanol decreased with increasing the temperature, indicating that a high temperature was preferable for the dehydration of 1-propanol to form propylene. On the other hand, the selectivity to propanal increased with increasing the temperature, suggesting that a high temperature was not preferable for the hydrogenation of propanal to form 1-propanol. The reaction results indicate that a moderate reaction temperature such as 280 °C prefers the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propylene. Table 9 shows the reaction results in the deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 with different catalyst dosages at 250 °C. The selectivity to propylene increased with increasing the catalyst dosage at a range of 0.5–2 g, while the selectivity to propanal, 1-propanol, acetone, and acetol decreased. A large catalyst dosage promoted either the hydrogenation of propanal to form 1-propanol or the dehydration of 1-propanol to form propylene. Meanwhile, a large catalyst dosage should also promote the conversion of acetone and acetol to form propylene (Table 4). Therefore, a high propylene selectivity of 92.1% with a complete conversion was achieved at a catalyst dosage of 2 g. On the other hand, a large catalyst dosage slightly promoted the formation of propane, which should be due to the further hydrogenation of propylene. In the deoxydehydration of diols to form olefins, the excessive hydrogenation of olefins to form alkanes is not expected. In the present study, the Cu-based catalysts showed a relatively poor activity for the hydrogenation of propylene to form propane even in an H2 atmosphere, which was an important cause for the highly selective production of propylene. In addition, a high propylene yield of 95.0% could be achieved over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 with a catalyst dosage of 2 g at 280 °C. Fig. 8 shows the changes in the conversion of 1,2-PDO and the selectivity to propylene over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 at 280 °C, and obvious catalyst deactivation is not observed during a time on stream of 24 h. 4 Conclusion Vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propylene was studied over various metal-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts, which were prepared by an impregnation method. Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 showed a good catalytic performance for the formation of 1-propanol, propanal, and propylene, while other metal-based catalysts, such as Pt-, Ru-, Rh-, Ni-, and Co-loaded SiO2-Al2O3, promoted the C-C cleavage of 1,2-PDO to form C1-C2 products. It was proposed that the vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over Cu-based catalysts underwent multi-step reactions including the dehydration of 1,2-PDO to form propanal, the hydrogenation of propanal to 1-propanol, and the dehydration of 1-propanol to propylene. Meanwhile, the Cu-based catalysts showed a relatively poor activity for the excessive hydrogenation of propylene to form propane even in an H2 atmosphere. The introduction of acidic components to the catalysts could further promote the catalytic performance. The 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst, which contained a large amount of acid sites with a high L/B ratio of 8.9, showed the best catalytic performance. The large amount of Lewis acid sites on 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 promoted the dehydration of 1-propanol to propylene, and the well dispersed Cu particles promoted the hydrogenation of propanal to 1-propanol. A moderate reaction temperature of 280 °C and a large catalyst dosage were beneficial for the selective production of propylene. A high propylene selectivity of 95.0% with a complete conversion was achieved in the vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO over 8Cu/10H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 at 280 °C, and the catalysts exhibited a good stability during a run of 24 h. coredata.dc:description: Vapor-phase catalytic deoxydehydration of 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) to form propylene was performed over various metal-loaded catalysts in an H2 flow at an ambient pressure. Cu-based catalysts exhibited a relatively high activity for the formation of propylene, while other metal-based catalysts, such as Pt-, Ru-, Rh-, Ni-, and Co-loaded SiO2-Al2O3, primarily produced C-C bond cleavage products. Cu-loaded H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts showed the best catalytic performance, and the catalyst with a Cu and H3PO4 loading of 8 and 10 wt%, respectively, could provide a propylene selectivity of 95.0% with a complete conversion of 1,2-PDO at 280 °C. The Cu-loaded H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts primarily contained Lewis acid sites, and the Cu particles were well dispersed on the catalyst surface with an averaged particle size of 3.1 nm. It is proposed that the vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-PDO to propylene undergoes multi-step reactions with propanal and 1-propanol as the reaction intermediates.
coredata.dc:title: Vapor-phase deoxydehydration of 1,2-propanediol to form propylene over Cu-loaded H3PO4/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst
